original_data.question: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician with several months of sharp, shooting pain in both legs. Twenty years ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved without treatment. He has no history of serious illness. Examination shows small pupils that constrict with accommodation but do not react to light. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the distal lower extremities. Patellar reflexes are absent bilaterally. His gait is unsteady and broad-based. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?

model_response:
The patient has a form of autonomic neuropathy associated with a loss of sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation to the heart, bladder, and bowel. The most common cause of this syndrome is diabetes mellitus. Patients are at risk for orthostatic hypotension, atrioventricular conduction block, gastrointestinal dysfunction, urinary retention, and erectile dysfunction. Mitral valve regurgitation is not associated with autonomic neuropathy. Penile squamous cell carcinoma is a possible complication of untreated syphilis, which can cause neuropathy. Thoracic aortic aneurysm is associated with atherosclerosis, which is not related to autonomic neuropathy. Trigeminal neuralgia is not associated with autonomic neuropathy.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Applied to pain that is described as sharp, i.e., sudden and severe. []
An intense sensation of discomfort or distress that radiates from one location to another sharply.
The inferior part of the lower extremity between the KNEE and the ANKLE.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Not causing physical or psychological misery, pain or distress.

The external reproductive organ of males. It is composed of a mass of erectile tissue enclosed in three cylindrical fibrous compartments. Two of the three compartments, the corpus cavernosa, are placed side-by-side along the upper part of the organ. The third compartment below, the corpus spongiosum, houses the urethra.
Return to the normal structure and/or function, e.g. the subsidence of a pathologic process, as the subsidence of an inflammatory lesion or new growth.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
Record and study of past events.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The aperture in the iris through which light passes.

The dioptric adjustment of the EYE (to attain maximal sharpness of retinal imagery for an object of regard) referring to the ability, to the mechanism, or to the process. Ocular accommodation is the effecting of refractive changes by changes in the shape of the CRYSTALLINE LENS. Loosely, it refers to ocular adjustments for VISION, OCULAR at various distances. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella. [HPO:probinson]
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Manner or style of walking.
An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia. [HPO:curators]
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The probability that an event will occur. It encompasses a variety of measures of the probability of a generally unfavorable outcome.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.
